b"b' avatars using transparency can look bad against non-white backgrounds'"
b'b" Some users have avatars with possibly unintentional transparency
column11: those avatars don\'t look good against a non-white background: ![rendered over previous background]url  Other avatars are well-designed for transparent display
column12: like our github gravatar: ![good transparency on gtihub avatar]url  It\'s probably best to backfill our images with white
column13: anything else will have surprising consequences."'

column10: b'b\' @TauPan I understand your concern. First
column11: the API page can serve as documentation. [it]url  says "List all issues across all the authenticated user\\xe2\\x80\\x99s visible repositories including owned repositories
column12: member repositories
column13: and organization repositories". So
column14: if the issues are created in the repository you don\\\'t own or you\\\'re not a member of
column15: then you simply cannot list the issues. These issues are not visible in other words. After all
column16: the reason why I closed this issue is because this is not a GitHub Android client\\\'s issue. And I don\\\'t think it\\\'s a bug in the API too. The concern is how we can enhance the API so that we can see all issues that we created ourselves regardless. And for you

column11: most of the bugs in the information displayed by the app are due to the Java API being quite outdated. Last week I tried to look into it to see how much effort would it mean to update that lib
column12: but haven\'t had the necessary time. I don\'t think it will be updated by the EGit guys (after such a long time without activity)
column13: so we should evaluate two options
column14: fixing it ourselves and sending them a PR or re-implement all the API with something like Retrofit."'

column10: b"b' Retrofit is a good option for implementing GitHub API wrapper and it can be added in small steps
column11: implementing API parts one by one'"

column10: b'b" Any updates on this
column11: what\'s the plan?"'

column10: b'b" I say we rip out the EGit classes we use and rewrite them one-by-one for API interaction. A large amount of my programming experience actually lies in dealing with JSON APIs (mainly in Python and JavaScript
column11: but I\'m sure I can handle it in Java). As Kevin said
column12: the Java API hasn\'t been updated in a long time. Maybe even work on the new version in a separate repository so others can use our Java wrapper in their projects? This would be a major undertaking because it would mean rewriting a large amount of the app\'s code
column13: but it would be worth it in the end (in my opinion) because we could document everything and know exactly how the code works to fix all the strange issues that manifest from the EGit classes."'

column10: b"b' [Fix #841] Fixed the complex class issue of NewsListAdapter'"

b"b' I like the integration tests of this project. I think it would be better if the gradle configuration of this project could support running unit tests. I inspected the code of this project using Android Studio and found the class NewsListAdapter was overly complex. The cyclomatic complexity of this class is 92. I want to add a unit test for this class and then refactor it. Unit tests are running faster than integration tests without connecting to a real Android phone or an emulator. After referring to the blog url  I changed the version of Android gradle plugin to be 1.1.0 and added junit in the dependencies. I added 18 unit tests for class IconAndViewTextManager. Now both the unit test and the original integration tests can be run smoothly in the Android Studio.'"
b"b' Refactored 17 if-else-if statements into enum constant-specific classes so that the complex class issue of class NewsListAdapter was fixed.'"
b"b' fixes #733 '"
b"b' Removed the empty file header.'"

column11: I think what you might not know yet
column12: is that you do not do **not** have to maintain _anything_ when adding your app to F-Droid. When gets added to the [Submission Queue]url  the GitHub source code of your project will be reviewed and the app added to F-Droid. Once you tagg and create a new release on GitHub
column13: the version will be _automatically compiled from source_ and published on F-Droid with the F-Droid signature. So don\'t get me wrong
column14: but I don\'t see _any_ reason why you shouldn\'t add it there since it is virtually no effort at all. May I add to the Submission Queue

column10: b'b" Not sure which API keys you mean
column11: @hzsweers. F-Droid compiles directly from the fresh source here on GitHub and signs the APK with [their own signature]url  I am sure their [FAQ]url  helps a bit answering questions.@F-Droid is an organization with FOSS at heart and I\'ve recently had the pleasure of getting huge help from them in every aspect when we added more build flavours in [AIMSICD]url  So should a problem exist
column12: anyone could log in on their [F-Droid GitLab]url  using their GitHub account and file an Issue. I could help
column13: too."'

column10: b'b" GitHub\'s API requires there be a registered \'application\' for each application that co sumes the API. Those registered apps have corresponding secret client API keys that are used for each request. For security reasons
column11: those secret keys should not be
column12: and as such would never be added to the PocketHub for repo.  So F-Droid certainly can build from this repo
column13: but it would not result in an apk that co rained a valid client secret
column14: and would not work against the GitHub API. See url "'

column10: b"b' Dupe of #819'"
b"b' Cache feed loads and show cached data during refresh'"
b"b' While we using viewpager and drawer to switch to a new page
column11: the new page will always loading data from internet even we have loaded before. Is it necessary to save the pages while they are in background and resume them when they are switched to front?'"

column10: b"b' Please add info about your build per  '"
b"b' The build is the latest master branch. As shown below
column11: when resume a page
column12: it will cost some time to load data. The performance is not well if the network is not good.![2016_02_02_11_56_16_667]url '"

column10: b'b\' This is not so much a "performance" issue as much as it is an implementation detail.  Specifically
column11: there\\\'s currently no caching done
column12: and you\\\'re kind of highlighting a worst case scenario (viewpager only keeps three pages in memory
column13: you\\\'re skipping to the 4th). Unfortunately I can\\\'t make your network perform faster
column14: nor do we want to rework viewpager to hold more than three pages in memory. If you swiped through the pages rather than only skipping to the first non-loaded page
column15: it would be fine.  It also makes sense for the gist and home pagers not to be reloaded at all considering they are totally independent components. So-as not to conflate
column16: your issue that you want caching. Caching is a nice-to-have pattern for the sake of having something to show during loading
column17: but not a high priority at the moment. \''

column10: b"b' In fact
column11: we can set the pages cached in viewpager by this code: While we change fragment according drawer
column12: it  well create a new fragment. My means is to store these pages and fragments. So when we returned to a page or fragment that have been loaded before
column13: we will not have to reload data from internet. If it is necessary
column14: I can push a PR.'"

column10: b'b" I don\'t want to do that. It\'s a very specific use case in the sense that it only helps if you go from index 0 -I dont\' want to do retained fragments either
column11: they\'ve historically been headaches for me (on top of the headaches that fragments already cause). I\'d rather a solid cache-based solution than bandaids."'

column10: b"b' OK
column11: thanks for your explanation.'"

column10: b'b" You can keep it open with the adjusted title

column10: b'b" @hzsweers would you be open to the idea of saving and restoring fragment state?  From what I understand
column11: the paged fragments depend on an instance of to decide initial view state
column12: what have been loaded so far and what to be loaded next. My rough idea would be to modify (or better one of its subclass to minimize impact) to support state restoration
column13: e.g. having a constructor which accepts saved state. Paged fragment can then reconstruct the instance based on a \'savedInstanceState\'
column14: and restore its state accordingly. Does this approach sound okay to you?"'

b"b' Remove welcome screen'"

b'b" The only information the welcome screen has is of a brief history of how the app came to be. I don\'t feel that this is necessary for the users to know. This information may be interesting to developers of the app
column11: and hence this information already being in the README seems like enough.  There are two main benefits to removing the welcome screen (which I can think of):  Allows the user to skip (imo) irrelevant information and allow them to login straight away. Removes all maintenance overhead that this component of the app entails (e.g. bugs
column12: translations)"'

column10: b'b" Well the feature is implemented and there should be no huge overhead of bugs to fix there. There is a skip button so if the user dosen\'t care they can skip early. So it will stay."'
b'b\' I feel this feature is making the experience worse
column11: even if there is a skip button. So the suggestion is to really just remove a bad feature. I guess this is just personal preference but generally when there is an intro screen like that
column12: it gives a quick  of what the app does
column13: not a history of how the app came to be.  Here are a few more thoughts to why the welcome screen should be removed:  The Welcome screen pictures add no substance to the experience as it is fairly unrelated to what the text says. The and are available only in two languages
column14: one of them being English. So though this feature may not have any program bugs but there is still maintenance required on it
column15: which is translating the text into multiple languages. The whole point of the welcome screen is boiled down to one sentence "So a while ago the GitHub app was discontinued and some of us wanted something new [so] we move[d] the app under a new name and are now PocketHub". Surely we don\\\'t need to add the many resources and Java classes associated with this feature just to get this one line across. If you still want this text
column16: we could just move it to the screen that prompts the user to press the "Login" button.  I\\\'m interested in having a bit more of a discussion (as stated in []url  Stating that we should keep a part of the app just because it is implemented without any further explanation as to why we should keep it is kind of offhand.\''

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: sorry about that. I\'ve had a rough week at work and should not have even commented earlier.  I do see the maintenance work for translations but that\'s not my biggest concern around the project right now.  For the user side I think we did it to push the old users over. So this might have served it\'s purpose.  So as is see it for now I\'d rather work on fixing up the thing that actually are broken than things that work and aren\'t hurting the app (which I don\'t think this is). But if you really feel that it\'s hurting the app then remove it or incorporate it better with the login flow maybe.  Once again sorry for just closing it like that
column12: will try to keep those to a minimum."'

column10: b'b" That\'s alright
column11: we all have those sort of weeks.  I agree that it is better to fix actual bugs
column12: but sometimes removing code bloat makes it easier to figure out where the problems are.  I\'m not sure whether it is better to just remove the information or incorporate in the login flow as you said. I\'ll take some time to mull it over or if you have any preference I\'d be interested in hearing it."'
